content: Good bye Black Water. Hello Triple Canopy. President Obama’s new mercenary firm of choice, Triple Canopy, will be officially taking over the job of protecting US occupation officials in Iraq from President Bush’s favorite hired guns, Blackwater, on May 7. But, as has been clear for some time, Obama may be changing the name, but the bloody game and its players are bound to remain virtually the same. The New York Times is now confirming that “many if not most of [Blackwater’s] private security guards will be back on the job in Iraq. The same individuals will just be wearing new uniforms, working for Triple Canopy.”(107) Triple Canopy + Airborne-Ranger-Special Forces. Just count the taps on the shoulder.

title: Obama hires new security company.

content: Ain't classified - unless it be relegated to the Want Adds - - http://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5gztXTGAKUSeJLN3dRjWpSUjkQ_ugD979Q2KG1 US replaces Blackwater for some Iraq security By MATTHEW LEE – Apr 1, 2009 WASHINGTON (AP) — The State Department said Wednesday it has signed the Virginia-based private security firm Triple Canopy to take over protecting U.S. diplomats on the ground in Iraq from Blackwater Worldwide, now known as Xe. Blackwater, which earlier this year changed its name to Xe (pronounced "Zee"), had come under heavy criticism for its alleged role in a fatal gun battle in Iraq. The Iraqi government refused to renew the firm's license to operate in the country. State Department spokesman Gordon Duguid said the government gave the job to Triple Canopy on Tuesday following a decision made in January not to renew Blackwater's contract..... Wandering and Wondering

title: Obama hires new security company.

content: armywife and Bergy - perhaps you missed the part about the Iraqi government refusing to allow Blackwater (under whatever name) to operate in the country? Seems like there was little choice in the matter for the US government: a change HAD to be made. Since those who possess the requisite skills are in somewhat short supply, it's no surprise that they would leave Blackwater and apply to Triple Canopy. As to why not use US soldiers, other than Marine guards at US embassies around the globe, the military is not used to protect most civilians, outside of those in certain high-ranking positions say, in DoD. Some military members accompany Congresscritters on CODELs - where they are usually treated not much better than porters and go-fers, so I can't say I can summon up much enthusiasm for further diluting the available pool of trained servicemembers. They have better things to do these days, IMNSHO.

content: Obama has nothing to do with hiring or firing of the contractors in country. The removal of Blackwater was in the works long before Obama came on board. I have several friends that have been in country since December working on the transition from Blackwater to the new company. There will be very few changes, the name of the company and the replacement of some in country management types. I am told the changeover of some in country personnel will take place as early as May.
reply: Obama has nothing to do with hiring or firing of the contractors in country. The removal of Blackwater was in the works long before Obama came on board. content: The situation with "Private Security Contractors" is like a double edged knife-they give the government hiring them some deniability, but they also aren't directly controlled by that gov't and can get out of control. They can hire away some of the best by virtue of astronomical pay, but they also can draw some of the worst who can't continue to make it in their units. Any government that has made long term use of mercenaries has always ran into one problem- after a while, they begin to think of themselves as a power unto themselves. Look back at Mad Mike Hoare- if he hadn't gotten caught early, the Seychelles would have been overthrown to make basically a mercenary homeland. We now have a situation where a private company has more armed troops, armed/armored vehicles, and armed aircraft than some small nations. Their plan to put armed vessels to sea may still cause problems- combat vessels at sea, not part of a nations forces, are classified as pirates, the same as those they are supposedly planning to oppose. Does anyone find it strange that whenever the State Dept would start talking about cut backs to PSCs, an incident would occur, usually involving PSC personnel engaging civilians, causing greater unrest and greater need for PSCs?
reply: The situation with "Private Security Contractors" is like a double edged knife-they give the government hiring them some deniability, but they also aren't directly controlled by that gov't and can get out of control. They can hire away some of the best by virtue of astronomical pay, but they also can draw some of the worst who can't continue to make it in their units. Any government that has made long term use of mercenaries has always ran into one problem- after a while, they begin to think of themselves as a power unto themselves. Look back at Mad Mike Hoare- if he hadn't gotten caught early, the Seychelles would have been overthrown to make basically a mercenary homeland. We now have a situation where a private company has more armed troops, armed/armored vehicles, and armed aircraft than some small nations. Their plan to put armed vessels to sea may still cause problems- combat vessels at sea, not part of a nations forces, are classified as pirates, the same as those they are supposedly planning to oppose. Does anyone find it strange that whenever the State Dept would start talking about cut backs to PSCs, an incident would occur, usually involving PSC personnel engaging civilians, causing greater unrest and greater need for PSCs?

Why not get rid of the private security and use the funds to recruit and train solders to provide security? For sure we'd have the best people and we'd be in a position to control situations as they arise. Because our so called diplomates, congressmen and foreign service people tend to treat the military security guards, embassy guards and body guards as nothing more than lowly hey boys.

content: quote: Originally posted by Vicdude: quote: Originally posted by greywolfghost: Ain't classified - unless it be relegated to the Want Adds - - http://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5gztXTGAKUSeJLN3dRjWpSUjkQ_ugD979Q2KG1 US replaces Blackwater for some Iraq security By MATTHEW LEE – Apr 1, 2009 WASHINGTON (AP) — The State Department said Wednesday it has signed the Virginia-based private security firm Triple Canopy to take over protecting U.S. diplomats on the ground in Iraq from Blackwater Worldwide, now known as Xe. Blackwater, which earlier this year changed its name to Xe (pronounced "Zee"), had come under heavy criticism for its alleged role in a fatal gun battle in Iraq. The Iraqi government refused to renew the firm's license to operate in the country. State Department spokesman Gordon Duguid said the government gave the job to Triple Canopy on Tuesday following a decision made in January not to renew Blackwater's contract..... title: Obama hires new security company.

content: The situation with "Private Security Contractors" is like a double edged knife-they give the government hiring them some deniability, but they also aren't directly controlled by that gov't and can get out of control. They can hire away some of the best by virtue of astronomical pay, but they also can draw some of the worst who can't continue to make it in their units. Any government that has made long term use of mercenaries has always ran into one problem- after a while, they begin to think of themselves as a power unto themselves. Look back at Mad Mike Hoare- if he hadn't gotten caught early, the Seychelles would have been overthrown to make basically a mercenary homeland. We now have a situation where a private company has more armed troops, armed/armored vehicles, and armed aircraft than some small nations. Their plan to put armed vessels to sea may still cause problems- combat vessels at sea, not part of a nations forces, are classified as pirates, the same as those they are supposedly planning to oppose. Does anyone find it strange that whenever the State Dept would start talking about cut backs to PSCs, an incident would occur, usually involving PSC personnel engaging civilians, causing greater unrest and greater need for PSCs?
reply: The situation with "Private Security Contractors" is like a double edged knife-they give the government hiring them some deniability, but they also aren't directly controlled by that gov't and can get out of control. They can hire away some of the best by virtue of astronomical pay, but they also can draw some of the worst who can't continue to make it in their units.
